org.prolobjectlink.prolog

Interface PrologEngine

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Iterable<PrologClause>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractEngine

    public interface PrologEngine
extends Iterable<PrologClause>
    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    Jose Zalacain

          • verify

            List<String> verify()
            Test the correct integration between under-laying prolog engine and top level interface. Return a string list with the needed conditions to link the under-laying prolog engine. if the under-laying prolog engine is linked the returned set only contain the "OK" string indicating a correct integration.
            Returns:
            string list with only "OK" string if the prolog engine integration is correct or the conditions string list needed to link the prolog engine.

            1.0

          • abolish

            void abolish(String functor,
             int arity)
            Remove all predicate that match with the predicate indicator (PI) formed by the concatenation of the given string functor and integer arity separated by slash (functor/arity). 
             engine.abolish("parent", 2); // remove all parent/2 predicates
            Parameters:
            functor - string functor that identify the predicate family to be remove.
            arity - argument number that identify the predicate family to be remove.
            Since:
            1.0

          • asserta

            void asserta(String stringClause)
            Parse the string creating internal prolog clause and add the clause in the main memory program if the clause non exist. If the clause exist, will not overwritten and the clause will not added. The string have prolog fact or rule syntax. The added clause will be the first clause for a clause lot with the same predicate indicator (PI). 
             engine.asserta("grandparent(X,Z):-parent(X,Y),parent(Y,Z)");
 engine.asserta("parent( pat, jim)");
 engine.asserta("parent( bob, pat)");
 engine.asserta("parent( bob, ann)");
 engine.asserta("parent( tom, liz)");
 engine.asserta("parent( tom, bob)");
 engine.asserta("parent( pam, bob)");
            Parameters:
            stringClause - - string for create internal prolog clause
            Since:
            1.0

          • asserta

            void asserta(PrologTerm head,
             PrologTerm... body)
            Add a rule specified by the rule head and rule body if the specified rule clause non exist. If the rule clause exist, will not overwritten and the clause will not added. The head term is the first argument and the body is constituted by the terms array followed of the rule head. If the body array is empty the clause will be considered like fact specified by head only. The added clause will be the first clause for a clause lot with the same predicate indicator (PI). The shared variables in the clause are declared once and use for build the terms that conform the clause to be added 
             String parent = "parent";
 String grandparent = "grandparent";
 
 PrologAtom pam = provider.newAtom("pam");
 PrologAtom bob = provider.newAtom("bob");
 PrologAtom ann = provider.newAtom("ann");
 PrologAtom pat = provider.newAtom("pat");
 
 PrologVariable x = provider.newVariable("X");
 PrologVariable y = provider.newVariable("Y");
 PrologVariable z = provider.newVariable("Z");
 
 engine.asserta(provider.newStructure(grandparent, x, z), provider.newStructure(parent, x, y),
                provider.newStructure(parent, y, z));
 engine.asserta(provider.newStructure(parent, pat, jim));
 engine.asserta(provider.newStructure(parent, bob, pat));
 engine.asserta(provider.newStructure(parent, bob, ann));
 engine.asserta(provider.newStructure(parent, tom, liz));
 engine.asserta(provider.newStructure(parent, tom, bob));
 engine.asserta(provider.newStructure(parent, pam, bob));
            Parameters:
            head - head of rule
            body - array of terms that compound the body of the rule
            Since:
            1.0

          • assertz

            void assertz(String stringClause)
            Parse the string creating internal prolog clause and add the clause in the main memory program if the clause non exist. If the clause exist, will not overwritten and the clause will not added. The string have prolog fact or rule syntax. The added clause will be the last clause for a clause lot with the same predicate indicator (PI). 
             engine.assertz("parent( pam, bob)");
 engine.assertz("parent( tom, bob)");
 engine.assertz("parent( tom, liz)");
 engine.assertz("parent( bob, ann)");
 engine.assertz("parent( bob, pat)");
 engine.assertz("parent( pat, jim)");
 engine.assertz("grandparent(X,Z):-parent(X,Y),parent(Y,Z)");
            Parameters:
            stringClause - string clause to be added
            Since:
            1.0

          • assertz

            void assertz(PrologTerm head,
             PrologTerm... body)

            Add a rule specified by the rule head and rule body if the specified rule clause non exist. If the rule clause exist, will not overwritten and the clause will not added. The head term is the first argument and the body is constituted by the terms array followed of the rule head. If the body array is empty the clause will be considered like fact specified by head only. The added clause will be the last clause for a clause lot with the same predicate indicator (PI). The shared variables in the clause are declared once and use for build the terms that conform the clause to be added 

             String parent = "parent";
 String grandparent = "grandparent";
 PrologAtom pam = provider.newAtom("pam");
 PrologAtom bob = provider.newAtom("bob");
 PrologAtom ann = provider.newAtom("ann");
 PrologAtom pat = provider.newAtom("pat");
 PrologVariable x = provider.newVariable("X");
 PrologVariable y = provider.newVariable("Y");
 PrologVariable z = provider.newVariable("Z");
 engine.assertz(provider.newStructure(parent, pam, bob));
 engine.assertz(provider.newStructure(parent, tom, bob));
 engine.assertz(provider.newStructure(parent, tom, liz));
 engine.assertz(provider.newStructure(parent, bob, ann));
 engine.assertz(provider.newStructure(parent, bob, pat));
 engine.assertz(provider.newStructure(parent, pat, jim));
 engine.assertz(provider.newStructure(grandparent, x, z), provider.newStructure(parent, x, y),
                provider.newStructure(parent, y, z));
            Parameters:
            head - head of rule
            body - array of terms that compound the body of the rule
            Since:
            1.0

          • clause

            boolean clause(String stringClause)
            Parse the string creating internal prolog clause and returning true if the clause in the main memory program unify with the given clause. If the clause not exist in main memory program or exist but not unify with the given clause false value is returned. The string have prolog fact or rule syntax. 
             boolean b = engine.clause("parent( pam, bob)");
 
             boolean b = engine.clause("grandparent(X,Z):-parent(X,Y),parent(Y,Z)");
            Parameters:
            stringClause - string clause to be match
            Returns:
            true if the clause in the main memory program unify with the given clause, false otherwise
            Since:
            1.0

          • clause

            boolean clause(PrologTerm head,
               PrologTerm... body)
            Find a rule specified by the rule head and rule body in main memory program that unify with the given clause returning true in this case.If the clause not exist in main memory program or exist but not unify with the given clause false value is returned. The head term is the first argument and the body is constituted by the terms array followed of the rule head. If the body array is empty the clause will be considered like fact specified by head only. The shared variables in the clause are declared once and use for build the terms that conform the clause to be found. 
             String parent = "parent";
 PrologAtom pam = provider.newAtom("pam");
 PrologAtom bob = provider.newAtom("bob");
 boolean b = engine.clause(provider.newStructure(parent, pam, bob));
 
             String grandparent = "grandparent";
 PrologVariable x = provider.newVariable("X");
 PrologVariable y = provider.newVariable("Y");
 PrologVariable z = provider.newVariable("Z");
 boolean b = engine.clause(provider.newStructure(grandparent, x, z), provider.newStructure(parent, x, y),
                provider.newStructure(parent, y, z));
            Parameters:
            head - head of rule
            body - array of terms that compound the body of the rule
            Returns:
            true if the clause in the main memory program unify with the given clause, false otherwise
            Since:
            1.0

          • retract

            void retract(String stringClause)
            Parse the string creating internal prolog clause and remove the clause in the main memory program if the clause exist. The string have prolog fact or rule syntax. 
             engine.retract("parent( pam, bob).");
 engine.retract("parent( tom, bob).");
 engine.retract("parent( tom, liz).");
 engine.retract("parent( bob, ann).");
 engine.retract("parent( bob, pat).");
 engine.retract("parent( pat, jim).");
 engine.retract("grandparent(X,Z):-parent(X,Y),parent(Y,Z)");
            Parameters:
            stringClause - string clause to be removed
            Since:
            1.0

          • retract

            void retract(PrologTerm head,
             PrologTerm... body)
            Remove a rule specified by the rule head and rule body if the specified rule clause exist. The head term is the first argument and the body is constituted by the terms array followed of the rule head. If the body array is empty the clause will be considered like fact specified by head only. The shared variables in the clause are declared once and use for build the terms that conform the clause to be removed. 
             String parent = "parent";
 String grandparent = "grandparent";
 PrologAtom pam = provider.newAtom("pam");
 PrologAtom bob = provider.newAtom("bob");
 PrologAtom ann = provider.newAtom("ann");
 PrologAtom pat = provider.newAtom("pat");
 PrologVariable x = provider.newVariable("X");
 PrologVariable y = provider.newVariable("Y");
 PrologVariable z = provider.newVariable("Z");
 engine.retract(provider.newStructure(parent, pam, bob));
 engine.retract(provider.newStructure(parent, tom, bob));
 engine.retract(provider.newStructure(parent, tom, liz));
 engine.retract(provider.newStructure(parent, bob, ann));
 engine.retract(provider.newStructure(parent, bob, pat));
 engine.retract(provider.newStructure(parent, pat, jim));
 engine.retract(provider.newStructure(grandparent, x, z), provider.newStructure(parent, x, y),
                provider.newStructure(parent, y, z));
            Parameters:
            head - head of rule
            body - array of terms that compound the body of the rule
            Since:
            1.0

          • unify

            boolean unify(PrologTerm t1,
              PrologTerm t2)
            Check that two terms (x and y) unify. Prolog unification algorithm is based on three principals rules:
            • If x and y are atomics constants then x and y unify only if they are same object.
            • If x is a variable and y is anything then they unify and x is instantiated to y. Conversely, if y is a variable then this is instantiated to x.
            • If x and y are structured terms then unify only if they match (equals funtor and arity) and all their correspondents arguments unify.
            Parameters:
            t1 - the term to unify.
            t2 - the term to unify.
            Returns:
            true if the specified term unify whit the current term, false otherwise.
            Since:
            1.0

          • contains

            boolean contains(String goal)
            Parse the string creating internal prolog clause and returning true if the given goal have solution using the resolution engine mechanism. If wrapped engine not support a dedicated method the query(goal).hasSolution()
            Parameters:
            goal - goal to be queried
            Returns:
            true if the given goal has solution
            Since:
            1.0

          • contains

            boolean contains(PrologTerm goal,
                 PrologTerm... goals)
            Check if the given goal array have solution using the resolution engine mechanism. If wrapped engine not support a dedicated method the query(goal).hasSolution()
            Parameters:
            goal - goal to be checked
            goals - goals array with the rest of conjunctive goals term (can be empty)
            Returns:
            true if the given goal has solution
            Since:
            1.0

          • query

            PrologQuery query(String query)
            Create a new query being the goal the given string with prolog syntax. The query creation process call the wrapped prolog engine and after query creation the query instance is ready to use. This particular query method can raise an syntax exception if the string query have prolog errors. 
             engine.query("parent(X, Y)");
            Parameters:
            query - string goal with prolog syntax.
            Returns:
            a new query instance.
            Since:
            1.0

          • query

            PrologQuery query(PrologTerm[] terms)
            Create a new query being the goal the given prolog term array. The given array is treated like a conjunctive goal and after success the first element the next term will be resolved. The query creation process call the wrapped prolog engine and after query creation the query instance is ready to use. 
             PrologTerm x = provider.newVariable("X", 0);
 PrologTerm dark = provider.newStructure("dark", x);
 PrologTerm big = provider.newStructure("big", x);
 PrologTerm[] goals = new PrologTerm[] { dark, big };
 engine.query(goals);
            Parameters:
            terms - prolog term array to be query.
            Returns:
            a new query instance.
            Since:
            1.0

          • query

            PrologQuery query(PrologTerm term,
                  PrologTerm... terms)
            Create a new query with at least one prolog term goal. The rest terms are treated like a conjunctive goal and after success the first element the next term will be resolved. The query creation process call the wrapped prolog engine and after query creation the query instance is ready to use. 
             PrologTerm x = provider.newVariable("X", 0);
 PrologTerm dark = provider.newStructure("dark", x);
 PrologTerm big = provider.newStructure("big", x);
 engine.query(dark, big);
            Parameters:
            term - prolog term to be query
            terms - prolog term array to be query.
            Returns:
            a new query instance.
            Since:
            1.0

          • queryOne

            Map<String,PrologTerm> queryOne(String goal)
            Create a new prolog query and return the prolog terms that conform the solution set for the current query. The solution set is a prolog terms map and every map entry is a pair variable name and variable instance value for the variables not anonymous involved in the query.
            Parameters:
            goal - string query with prolog format.
            Returns:
            variable name - variable instance (key - value) map that conform the solution set for the current query.
            Since:
            1.0

          • queryOne

            Map<String,PrologTerm> queryOne(PrologTerm term,
                                PrologTerm... terms)
            Create a new prolog query and return the prolog terms that conform the solution set for the current query. The solution set is a prolog terms map and every map entry is a pair variable name and variable instance value for the variables not anonymous involved in the query.
            Parameters:
            term - prolog term to be query
            terms - prolog term array to be query.
            Returns:
            variable name - variable instance (key - value) map that conform the solution set for the current query.
            Since:
            1.0

          • operator

            void operator(int priority,
              String specifier,
              String operator)
            Define an operator in the wrapped prolog engine with priority between 0 and 1200 and associativity determined by specifier according to the table below
            Specification table
            Specifier Type Associativity
            fx prefix no
            fy prefix yes
            xf postfix no
            yf postfix yes
            xfx infix no
            yfx infix left
            xfy infix right
            Parameters:
            priority - operator priority between 0 and 1200
            specifier - associative and position of the operator
            operator - operator to be defined
            Since:
            1.0

          • currentPredicate

            boolean currentPredicate(String functor,
                         int arity)
            Check if in the wrapped prolog engine is defined some particular predicate specified by your predicate indicator (PI = functor/arity). If the predicate is defined by prolog engine built-in or by user definition return true and false in other case. If wrapped engine not support a dedicated method the currentPredicate(String, int) will be defined like currentPredicates().contains(new PredicateIndicator(functor, arity));
            Parameters:
            functor - name of the predicate to be check.
            arity - argument number of the predicate to be check.
            Returns:
            true in functor/arity predicate is defined and false otherwise.
            Since:
            1.0

          • currentOperator

            boolean currentOperator(int priority,
                        String specifier,
                        String operator)
            Check if in the wrapped prolog engine is defined some particular operator specified by your Priority, Specifier and Operator. If the operator is defined by prolog engine built-in or by user definition return true or false in other case. If wrapped engine not support a dedicated method the currentOperator(int, String, String) will be defined like currentOperators().contains(new PrologOperator(priority, specifier, operator));
            Parameters:
            priority - operator priority between 0 and 1200
            specifier - associative and position of the operator
            operator - operator to be checked
            Returns:
            true if the operator is defined by prolog engine built-in or by user definition, false otherwise.
            Since:
            1.0

          • currentPredicates

            Set<PrologIndicator> currentPredicates()
            Predicate set defined in the wrapped prolog engine. The predicate set will be constituted by the supported built-ins predicate in the wrapped prolog engine and user defined predicates present in the prolog program/database.
            Returns:
            Defined Predicate Set.
            Since:
            1.0

          • currentOperators

            Set<PrologOperator> currentOperators()
            Operator set defined in the wrapped prolog engine. The operator set will be constituted by the supported built-ins operator in the wrapped prolog engine and user defined operators present in the prolog program/database.
            Returns:
            defined operator set.
            Since:
            1.0

          • getProgramMap

            Map<String,List<PrologClause>> getProgramMap()
            Make and return a copy of the clause map present in the current engine. The map key is a functor/arity string and the value is a prolog clause family list.
            Returns:
            a clause map present in the current engine.
            Since:
            1.0

          • getProgramClauses

            Set<PrologClause> getProgramClauses()
            Make and return a copy of the clause set present in the current engine.
            Returns:
            a clause set present in the current engine.
            Since:
            1.0

          • getProgramSize

            int getProgramSize()
            Number of clauses in the current engine.
            Returns:
            number of clauses in the engine.
            Since:
            1.0

          • isProgramEmpty

            boolean isProgramEmpty()
            Check if the program in main memory is empty returning true if the clause number in the program is 0 and false in otherwise. If wrapped engine not support a dedicated method isProgramEmpty() will be defined like PrologEngine#getProgramSize()==0;.
            Returns:
            true if the clause number in the program is 0 and false in otherwise.
            Since:
            1.0

          • dispose

            void dispose()
            Clear program in main memory. Release all resources used and prepare the current engine for realize some new task.
            Since:
            1.0
